file_name: Zhang 等 - 2022 - Robust Adaptive Neural Control for Wing-Sail-Assisted Vehicle via the Multiport Event-Triggered Appr.pdf

structured_info.title_cn: 基于多端口事件触发方法的翼帆辅助船舶鲁棒自适应神经控制
structured_info.title_en: Robust Adaptive Neural Control for Wing-Sail-Assisted Vehicle via the Multiport Event-Triggered Approach
structured_info.abstract: This article presents a robust adaptive neural control algorithm for the wing-sail-assisted vehicle to track the desired waypoint-based route, where the event-triggered mechanism is with the multiport form. The main features include reduced communication burden via multiport event-triggering, sail force compensation for energy-saving propeller operation, and neural-network approximation of system uncertainties combined with robust neural damping and dynamic surface control techniques. Lyapunov analysis proves semiglobal uniform ultimate bounded stability, validated through simulations and experiments.
structured_info.methodology: Multiport event-triggered control, RBF neural network approximation, robust neural damping, dynamic surface control (DSC), Lyapunov stability analysis
structured_info.conclusion: The proposed algorithm achieves effective path tracking with reduced communication burden and energy consumption. Stability is proven via Lyapunov theory, with simulations and practical experiments confirming robustness against uncertainties and disturbances.

analysis.Overview: Presents a neural control algorithm for path-following of sail-assisted marine vehicles using multiport event-triggering to reduce communication load and energy consumption.
Background_and_Motivation: Addresses fuel energy crisis challenges in marine systems and instability from sail dynamics/environmental disturbances.
Aims to reduce communication burden in sensor-controller-actuator channels while handling system uncertainties.
Highlights urgency through energy efficiency demands and limitations of existing adaptive control methods.
Links specific sail-assisted vehicle control to broader marine automation sustainability goals.
Contributes to control theory, marine robotics, and neural network applications.
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: 1) Multiport event-triggered control: Independent actuator channel management via error-triggered updates. 2) Sail force compensation: Energy optimization using wind/heading data. 3) Neural uncertainty approximation: RBF-NNs with norm-based adaptive parameters.
Event-triggering reduces communication, sail compensation minimizes propeller energy, and neural approximation handles uncertainties.
Assumes bounded disturbances, passive sway stability, and reference path generated by virtual ship.
Provides methodological innovation in adaptive control with reduced computational load and theoretical contribution to event-triggered stability proofs.
Methodology: Multiport event-triggered mechanism, RBF-NN uncertainty approximation, robust neural damping, DSC, Lyapunov stability analysis.
Novelty in error-based triggering (vs. input variation), applicability to underactuated marine systems, rational through stability guarantees.
Simulation: 12m vessel model with physical disturbance models. Experiment: INAC-3 vehicle data from GPS/gyrocompass. Preprocessing includes sail coefficient fitting.
Rigorous Lyapunov-based stability proof with SGUUB, adequate metrics (MATE, MACI, MTIV) for performance evaluation.
Follows Lyapunov-based nonlinear control paradigm, influencing robustness-focused design.
Results: Higher tracking accuracy than baselines, reduced channel load (56% fewer transmissions), energy savings via sail compensation, exclusion of Zeno behavior.
Results significant for marine energy efficiency; reliability demonstrated through simulation-experiment consistency; stability maintained across wind/wave disturbances.
Argumentation_and_Logic: Structured: Problem formulation → Control design → Stability proof → Validation.
1) Model system dynamics 2) Design event-triggering 3) Derive adaptive laws 4) Prove stability 5) Validate empirically.
Strengths: Comprehensive Lyapunov analysis. Weaknesses: Simplified roll dynamics assumption addressed via keel justification.
Strengths_and_Limitations: Multiport event-triggered innovation, energy-efficient sail compensation, reduced computational load via norm-based adaptation.
Assumes bounded disturbances; ignores heel dynamics; SGUUB stability (not asymptotic).
Lyapunov framework constrains conclusions to bounded-error stability.
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: Advances marine control discourse by integrating event-triggering with sail dynamics.
Specialized terminology (e.g., SGUUB, DOF), technical tone, rhetorical emphasis on three-fold novelty.
Builds authority through control-theoretic rigor and citations contrasting prior event-triggered approaches.
Conclusions_and_Implications: Achieves stable path-following with communication/energy efficiency validated in simulations and real experiments.
Extend to multi-vehicle systems, improve disturbance rejection, and explore hardware optimization.
